name: DCS World Steam Edition
description: Feel the excitement of flying the Su-25T "Frogfoot" attack jet and the TF-51D "Mustang" in the free-to-play Digital Combat Simulator World!DCS World is a vehicle combat simulation game created by an inspired development team. DCS World uses a powerful engine that delivers realistic gameplay.
minimum_requirements: Minimum system requirements (LOW graphics settings):   OS 64-bit Windows 7/8/10; DirectX11; CPU: Intel Core i3 at 2.8 GHz or AMD FX; RAM: 8 GB (16 GB for heavy missions); Free hard disk space: 60 GB; Discrete video card NVIDIA GeForce GTX 760 / AMD R9 280X or better; requires internet activation.
recommended_requirements: Recommended system requirements (HIGH graphics settings):  OS 64-bit Windows 8/10; DirectX11; CPU: Core i5+ at 3+ GHz or AMD FX / Ryzen; RAM: 16 GB (32 GB for heavy missions); Free hard disk space: 120 GB on Solid State Drive (SSD); Discrete video card NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1070 / AMD Radeon RX VEGA 56 with 8GB VRAM or better; Joystick; requires internet activation.  Recommended VR systems requirements (VR graphics settings):  OS 64-bit Windows 8/10; DirectX11; CPU: Core i5+ at 3+ GHz or AMD FX / Ryzen; RAM: 16 GB (32 GB for heavy missions); Free hard disk space: 120 GB on Solid State Drive (SSD); Discrete video card NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 / AMD Radeon RX VEGA 64 or better; Joystick; requires internet activation.

reviews.review_text: After a long week blowing up ISIS in my A-10, I revel in the relaxing feeling of blowing up virtual ISIS in my virtual A-10.

This game, or more accurately, simulator, is one of the best games I have played in a VERY long time. No matter what your taste in aircraft or flying may be, there is fun to be had in DCS.  You can purchase aircraft from a wide number of time periods, from WWII, The Korean War, and even modern battlefields. There's also some very nice helicopters to purchase, but I can't comment on those, as I don't have any.. ;-;  If you like CAS, BVR, Dogfighting or just screwing around with friends in fast aircraft, DCS World is most certainly worth trying. The free aircraft you get, the SU-25T and TF-51 give you a pretty good feel for what you can expect in DCS, but I definitely reccomend picking up a full fidelty module if you like it, great fun learning what all the alarms mean... ._.  One quick note though, getting the game directly from the developers is a better choice than Steam, as the version from ED's site gives you earlier access to new modules, updates, and let's you buy modules from sales on ED's site AND Steam, which cannot be done with the Steam version ;D  tl;dr : BUY IT AND YOU CAN CRASH TOO :D

Outright the best aircraft and helicopter simulator on the market. The only negative part: You can never fly any other simulator again. (Because you will miss the fidelity of DCS)  A small warning though: This is a simulator, not a game. So expect to invest many hours of learning how to handle your craft. If you are willing to learn, this simulator will be immensely rewarding to you.

I saw this 'game' on steam one day, and was like 'meh it's for free let me try it'.  A week later.....  *while printing ~300 pages of manuals and charts* Friend: What are you doing? Me: The closest thing to an airforce pilot I can do

An amazingly well done flight sim. Sure, if you're in reality a terrible pilot with bad habits it's going to be really hard to retrain yourself from the hand holding of other well known flight sims. Reality check #1, you can't expect to land at full speed. #2 Your 20, 000 pound Su-25 or A10 won't turn on a dime unless you know how to make the beast obey your wishes.#3 this is a very unforgiving and realistic sim. You WILL be shot down a hundred times before you learn to actually evade enemy fire.   Also, you really can't blame the developer for the user being too lazy to actually read the manual provided/available to each aircraft. I mean, if somebody's too lazy to read the mission briefing that describes the campaign progression why would you expect them to read the manual?   In conclusion this game isn't for the lazy or weak willed. It's for those that want the satisfaction of seeing an a10 at the local airshow and knowing you could start that sucker up and off the runway and navigate anywhere you want to go. While using any and all real world equipment in that airframe.  For me 10/10 for this high quality sim, DLCs as DCS definitely worth every penny
Just sitting in the cockpit on the runway in VR mode with HTC Vive is enough to give this a thumbs up.

Just bought it today, I don't have the slightest clue what I'm doing, but the game is great in just about every way from what I've seen of it.  The learning curve is very high in this game, but it's well worth the time and effort!  It even comes with an ARMA style mission editor! Though this one is a bit more complicated, there is so much potential!!  The fact I have work in the morning makes me sad.
One of the Best Flight Sims I've ever played. Just wish the Price of the Aircraft came down abit

That feeling when I got my first muliplayer kill in the MiG-21, and with guns, is something I can't explain with words. And it was only an A-10C.   The satisfaction when, after tons of hours of practice, of mastering an airplane, its systems, weapons, etc, you get to use it properly and succeed, that kind of satisfaction I haven't experienced it in any other game, even when playing team vs team tournaments in tactical FPS games.   I can only say: if you are into flight simulation, into fighters, attack aircraft or helicopters, go for it. The simulation of most of the modules is superb.     Yes, I know it can get expensive, but actually I wouldn't recommend getting a lot of modules when starting. Get a module you think you will like and start invesing hours in it, and learning the aircraft and to be able to fly it as if you've been doing it for years. Then go to multiplayer and show what you are worth. First it will be all frustration, but after some time and experience, when you start acomplishing your objectives it will be extremely rewarding.     One last thing to say, and being an X-Plane 10 player I noticed really quickly, the clouds on this game are extremely optimized and look fantastic.
Super good graphics. Nice HD Models. Can't get enough!

This is probably the most realistic flight simulator out there (with the non FC3 aircraft). In this simulator it is no game, you have to learn how to fly, operate avionics, radios and weapons. Even though the learning curve for the advanced aircraft might seem big there are interactive tutorials that will teach you, which is better than reading some of the multi-hundred page manuals (which should be read when wanting to know how to operate something in the plane if the tutorial missed something). The world in this game is huge, mountains, ocean, towns/ cities. You can achieve long range flights with the map size. Also there is aireal refueling (only with the A-10C and most FC3 aircraft) which caters even more to long range flights. As some of you probably knew before you read this, that DCS is a combat simulator. So on top of having planes with realistic flight characteristics and avionics, you also have the ability to use that planes' weapons. The weapons are just as realistic as the planes, and yes, bombing with planes like F-86F is just as hard as it always was for the real pilots.  The only thing that is missing from DCS is more modern fighters that are not like FC3 aircraft, so far the A-10C is the only modern plane (but it is only a A/G aircraft) and from what I heard the F/A-18C is coming to DCS so hopefully it will expand the variety of planes and helicopters in the future

1:1 simulations sound like your thing? Do you like spending 20 minutes just to get through the start-up process (that is also 1:1 simulated) of your aircraft? Do you reallllllly want to find out what that red button does in the corner? Then this game is for you!

Was going to play IL-2 Sturmovik Battle of Stalingrad, bought an X52 non pro to do so. Decided i'd try DCS WORLD and see if it really was that great.   Spent 27 hours this last week playing it as a SU 27 pilot. So what am i saying?  This is a great game, you need to give it a few hours to learn the aircraft and set the controls but when you know everything this is so much fun. I can't get enough of this game and i've only played the SU 27 so far.  Thank you DCS!

It's daunting at first and some of the tutorials are not as useful as I'd hoped but stick with it and check out youtube for good how-to guides and you'll be flying in no time.  Multiplayer is another step up but flying missions with other players is fantastic fun!

I love this Simulator. Im addicted to DCS World because of the quality and realism of both the Sim and the Module´s (DLC). i recommend using a joystick or HOTAS, even a cheap one is good enough. the prices of the Module´s maybe seems high but in my opinion worth every cent because of the high quality of them. I recommending this Sim for all flight sim enthusiasts.   I give DCS World 5/5
Best simulator game EVER. I am waiting for F-14 Tomcat and F-18 Hornet ! Full simulation please !!
got the plane started finally got it to move rolled it over n exsploded 11/10 would do again
Awesome game. Need to put the time into it to fly correctly and learn all of the modules.
Best modern air COMBAT simulator you are going to find.

This is a fantastic simulator and game. I've spent many hours before the steam integration and have bought a flight stick, rudder pedals, and track ir because of this sim. If you love hardcore simulations that require patience and a little bit of study then this is for you.  There aren't as many planes as other simulators, but what this simulator has over ALL others is quality. Both free modules (SU-25T 'Frogfoot' & TF-51D 'Mustang'), and the full modules (A-10C, Ka-50, Huey, Mi-8, P-51d and others) have very detailed flight models (physics) and fully interactive cockpits (for you button/switch lovers out there). You can fly all the modules this sim has to offer without a keyboard; as long as you have a mouse (to interact with the cockpit buttons/switches) and a flight stick/throttle for your HOTAS (hands on throttle and stick).  Once you're comfortable in single player, you absolutely must try out multiplayer. I still remember my first couple experiences joining a multiplayer server in the A-10C (my favorite module so far). I joined their teamspeak channel and had a commander barking orders, ka-50's shouting rifle left and right, and the whole time I had an f-15c fly beside me who I thought was escorting me, but later I realised he was simply practicing his sortie/formation flight.  The reward you feel for learning how to start, take off, fly/operate, then land an aircraft with this level of detail is an amazing experience. I warn you though, this is a simulation first and a game second so be prepared to put in time (around 10 hours) and effort towards the steep learning curve before you expect to have fun.

Keen on reading pages after pages of manuals on radar systems, auto pilots, flight controlls and what not? Feel the urge to be shot down time after time again by enemy SAM stations and fighters? Do you have a desperate need to struggle with control mapping, button possitioning and horrible flying weather?  If yes, continue reading. If no, move on.  Because if you get past all of the earlier mentioned struggles and frustrations this simulator is fantastically rewarding! The feeling you get when you land your first bombing run spot on or shoot down your first enemy fighter with a AMRAM missile is absolutely superb! If you choose to put in the hours requiered, this simulator is absolutely breathtaking!  Do keep in mind that this is a simulator much more than it is a game. Therefore it is not for those who is not willing to lay down the time and effort to get it just right. Furter more you ABSOLUTELY need a joystick and throttle. Preferably a seperated joystick, throttle and peddals. I use the Thrustmaster HOTAS Warthog setup along side the Saitek PRO rudder pedals, and this works wonderfully.  I am curently awaiting my Oculus Rift and can not wait to pair it up with this sim!
I would recommend this game to anybody!!! I love this game!! I would recommend that you download it from the DCS website. They have faster updates then Steam can get.
If you are looking for a flight combat simulator...this is it.
Amazing, stunning and realistic. Very high learning curve, and I liked that. Friendly community towards noobies. Just... epic.
If you want to be a pilot, this is the game for you. And if you dont like it, just remember at least its free!
Got engines started, started rolling after trying to figure out how to start the engines for about 5 hours. Wing collided with a building Exploded  11/10 would fly again :D
Great game for any one wanting a bit of realism without going for all out realism like Falcon BMS. Also I call for a rename of this game. It should be called Button Simulator!
Amazing sim! Very complex and you will need a joystick!

It's the best flight sim in the world. There simply is no substitute for CAS aircraft simulation. Falcon BMS provides a great F16 simulator. However, for everything else DCS is superior in every way. The A10C is the most faithfully recreated aircraft in their line up. But you can still have a great time flying the Russian black shark. The feeling you get when you successfully start an aircraft from a cold start is amazing. You also get to try out the SU25 for free (and the modern version for a price). it's not nearly as fun as the A10C, but it still lets you learn the basic weapon systems. It's VERY IMPORTANT to remember that the A10 is NOT the same as the A10C. the A10 will get you a more forgiving 'arcadey' aircraft (but still more realistic then something like say ace combat or battlefield, think of the old Jane's flight sims level). the A10C will give you the real deal. The A10C package does include basic tutorials for things like learning how to properly fly/start/land/engage in an A10. But things like working with JTAC will not be explained. So quite a bit of reading is required on your part.
Stunning military flight simulation, especially that A10 module. So indepth it has literally taken me 50hrs just to learn the controls :-) enjoying every second of this game! :-)
DCS World: a great flying simulator, and it's FREE!

DCS happen to be 'the' flight sim developers right now, and their numerous flyable aircraft offer a high degree of detail and realism that is unsurpassed in the military flight sim genre. The Ka-50 Black Shark helicopter, and the A-10 C Warthog for example, are two highly detailed aircraft that will take most budding pilots weeks to get to grips with, let alone master. Fortunately, DCS World provides a more immediate introduction to the flying module without the extremely high learning curve in say the A-10C, and with a reasonable joy stick, you'll be flying fairly quickly. There are several aircraft to pilot, including the F15, Su27, Su33, Mig 29S, and the Su25. The flight modeling is exceptional and level of world detail extremely high. I would recommend having a fairly high end PC to really enjoy the physics and visuals in the game - it is processor heavy. Ideally, you probably want to invest in a joy-stick and possibly flight pedals down the road, if you really want to immerse yourself in the art of combat flying. I've been playing for several weeks now getting to grips with the Su-27, and it's been suitably challenging, offering a lot return playability. Cranked up to full realism, and this quickly becomes a very, very challenging simulator - which of course is where a lot of the joy comes from. Be prepated to be truly immersed in the flight environment.

DCS World is one of the few games I can really enjoy at any time of the day.. Its communities (eg hoggit) tend to be quite welcoming and friendly to all types of players, and that is huge plus.. DCS of course, has a variety of aircraft, mostly purchased ones for around $40, I would recommend picking up A-10C ASAP. Graphically, the game is quite nice (in the air), but ground textures are lacking in certain aspects, but EDGE should in theory fix this, along with some performance problems on older rigs. Overall, 10\10 gud gume 60 fps no crash
It's kind of like dust II but different.

So I just finished downloading this game today and found out how to take off in the SU-25. After spending 15 minutes in a mission thinking 'I'll just throw myself into the fire' and dropping my landing gear, deploying flares and using my parachutes without getting off the ground once, I decided to use the tutorial. In the next 45 minutes, I learned how to take off, but not after running off the runway twice, overcorrecting while turning to get onto the runway and rolling the plane, and crashing into one of the trucks driving into the taxiing area. 10/10 Would recommend to anyone who doesn't mind trial and error. I know I'll be playing this for a long time.
The graphics are great. Everything from creating missions to playing online is endless hours of fun. A little hard to learn the controls at the beginning, but definately worth it. 10/10

WOW! This flight sim is over the top! I just can't get enough of it. The flight models are superior to every other flight sim I have tried. The details of the planes and cockpits are beautiful and having the freedom to click every button and switch, just adds to the experience. The cockpit layouts are spot on. Every item is where it should be as in real life. Flight mechanics are awesome as well. As real as it gets for a flight sim! Learning how to fly these aircraft can be a challenge, but most modules have 'training exercises' to help you figure out what to do. Flight manuals can also be found online, on steam or at the DCS website. There are also traning videos on Youtube. I personally enjoy the A10-C Warthog. The experience in the A10-C is intense and it is such a spectacular flight model. The other aircraft are awesome as well. Flying the Russian birds and hearing the Russian radio chat is great! There are so many positive things to say about this title I would be here all day, but I would rather be gunning down soldiers or blowing stuff up on the awesome missions or campaign! See you in the skies, pilots!
Best Flight Sim on planet Earth.

By far the greatest combat sim you can get your hands on. First module you should get is the A10C then get yourself the TM Warthog. Its the closest you'll get to flying the real thing.  The A10C is one of the most complex aircraft in DCS. If you sort of know your way around the A10C the other modules become a lot easier to learn and figure out so its defintely a good module to start with and one of the cheapest.  DCS takes time so if thats not your thing than its probably not for you. The manual for the A10C is 671 pages to give you an idea of how complex it is. This is the reason these aircraft are 'expensive'. You are basically flying the real thing  I have a lot more than 83hrs as I dont use the Steam version

This game is simply amazing. I found this game browsing Steam and decided to give it a try. Given that the SU-25T module is free, I figured that it would be low quality and very limited in its playability. The complete opposite is true! The plane proved a pleasure to fly and I thoroughly enjoyed the challenge offered in mastering the plane. The first time I was able to take off from an airfield, find a tank convoy, attack it successfully, and return to base, I was sold. The game sucked me in and I knew I had to buy some new modules. I decided on the A-10A, F-15C, and SU-27 modules. The planes are beautifully modeled and each one offers a unique approach to their specific role. Although the learning curve is steep (especially steep for the A-10C, I hear), the reward of mastering an aircraft is unmatchable in comparison to any other game I've ever played. The game offers fantastic gameplay for those who are into heavy ground-pounding aircraft like the A-10 or SU-25 and for those of us who dream of being the Top Gun and dominating the sky. I haven't tried any of the helicopter modules, but they're next on my list. Those looking for a challenging game and are military jet fans should definitely try this game. 10/10!

I climb into the pilot seat of my Bell UH-1. After following start up procedures and insuring everything is in working order I slowly raise the collective. My bird starts to steadily lift off the ground though it wants to spin to the right. I rudder till it is straightened out and continue to ascend, wobbly. I leave the confines of the airfield I took off from and make my way to a nearby city, making long sweeping turns as I go. This isn't so bad I think to myself. I've seen videos of people trying to fly and hardly getting off the ground, I guess ArmA3's advanced flight model actually payed of! After a flying around the city for a few minutes, turn my attention back to the airport. Is that a C-130 I see? Surely it is. I have to go get a closer look. I make a beeline for the airport, my instrument panel shaking violently as I proceed at dangerous speeds. As I approach the plane, seeing that it is indeed a C-130, I spot a C-17. I've got to check that out too, I pull back on my stick and to the left, lower the collective a bit and rudder into the most beautiful turn I've ever seen. Across the flight line I spot a 707 chasis. I wonder if that is a KC-135! I take off in it's direction. As I approach from the front I realise that I am going to have to make a near 180 in order see the rear of the aircraft to see if it is infact a KC-135. I pull the stick hard to the right, but I was coming in too fast and forgot to correct my collective. Panic sets in as I watch the altimeter rapidly tick lower and lower. Now is not my time. I hammer up on the collective and continue to bring the helicopter around. An alarm goes off, I assume it to be alerting me to the rapidly approaching ground, no such luck. The helicopter lurches upward at an alarming rate, the alarm doesn't stop. Suddenly I hear a loud *CLUNK* I think to my self, 'What the hell was that?' I then realise that it suddenly got a lot quieter, the sound of blades cutting through the air no longer a constant droning. Infact it isn't their at all. Alarmed I look around and spot my blades hurdling through the air. I quickly apologize to my stoic faced co-pilot, he seems to have resigned to our fate. Nonetheless I punch at the controls to no avail. In a short moment we slam into the tarmac, exploding in a fireball of glory behind the aircraft I was so eager to check out. I never found out if it was a KC-135 or not.   10/10

Let me see... We could write for hours how amazing this game is but we dont have time for that. It's an awsome simulation air combat game. If you want to try it please you must have an open mind a be mindwilling to overcome the hard knowledge of each and one of the aircrafts from the simple commands to the advance ones. Fly Safe

A few of my friends have been playing this for a while, and I've been dying to get it. I recently built a decent computer and decided to take the plunge into throwing hours of my life at the screen. I bought the F-15 module just to try it out, and although disappointed the F-16 has not been modeled (Yet), the Eagle is a stellar combat platform. Coming from a background in civil aviation and being type rated on Cessna 172XP, I can vouch for how realistic the flight model feels. It really (to the extent that my controls can convey) feels like you are being buffeted by wind at low speeds, you can 'feel' the aircraft as is starts to lose lift, and after a few hours you start being able to read the aircraft, when it is about to stall, the best roll to turn, AoA for climbing at the edge, you become one with the aircraft. Switching from one plane to another really throws your head for a loop. They've really got the effect of feeling what the aircraft is doing damn near perfect. I don't think even FSX models ground effect as realistically (read: scary as F***) as this game does. It truly is a simulation. Pull the stick back and cut the throttle, as the aircraft starts to shake and the wing starts to dip, adrenaline kicks in. It is unreal. I've never gotten such a physical response from a game before. The weight of the weapon and fuel payload is completely dynamic. I found myself flying touch-and-go landings for hours, working towards getting my glide slope and flare *just* right, only to restart and realize my pitch angles and approach speeds had to be entirely different from when I ended the last time, due to being fully loaded again.   This is not a game you can pick up and start dominating in within a few minutes. You need to dedicate hours upon hours learning the airframe you want to excel in, and stick to it. It will frustrate you, it will make you never want to hold a flight stick again, but once you get your first kill, or the first time you successfully take on fuel from a flying tanker, the amount of excitement you feel is incredible. Getting sweaty palms from holding the aircraft perfectly in formation so as to not get a fuel boom in your turbine is great. Getting a radar contact at 80 miles, and have to watch his blip get closer and closer, until finally entering the weapon effective range had me on the edge of my seat. I find myself running through my last sortie in my head while I'm at work, thinking of what I could have done differently, better tactics to use, strategies to try. It is amazingly addicting.   I've logged 14 hours over the last few days, and I see myself putting in quite a few more late nights, flying hundreds of sorties. I haven't even delved into the online world yet. I am hesitant simply because I know there are thousands of people online who would make me look like I've never even flown a paper airplane before, and I don't want to make a fool of myself. Yet. :)  I think the only downside to this simulator is quite simply how steep the learning curve is. I'm sure there will be quite a few people who can't take off, get angry and say this game is broken. Take it slow, do the lessons, and most importantly, READ THE MANUAL! Yeah, most of them are close to 200 pages, but like I said earlier, your first kill will make that completely worth it.  I would highly suggest that if you are an aviation fanatic, like a challenge, and want to get as close as you can to pushing the throttles to the forward stop in a variety of combat aircraft without joining the military, get this game. I can only sit back and wonder how they are going to improve DCS:W in their second iteration, because from my perspective, the mechanics of it are spot on.
This is not a game. This is a way of life

If you are interested in military flight sims why not take a look at DCS World. Considering its free you can try it and realise first hand how hard it is to actually jump into an aircraft and figure out whats going on.  DCS World also includes a mission editor much like Arma 3, fully customizable and scriptable.  Great study sim for the experienced, or even causal flyer who want to sit up in the air. Would recommend the A-10C module (DLC)  Beautiful game.

This is a Sim not for those who simply want to jump in and fly arcade style.  On my computer I can only run it at MEDIUM settings and get arroung 17 - 20 FPS it's playable but I've only played free flight and some of the training, so not sure how it would go with more happening.  My specs: Windows 7 Home Premium (64bit)SP1 Intel Core i7-2670QMCPU @ 2.20GHz, 16GB Ram, Nvidia GTX 560M 2GB  I have a few bugs when I first try to load it up it tends to freeze running 'Task Manager' (CTRL ALT DEL) then going back into the game without closing it down seems to get things going. I have no idea why that works.  There is a very large learning curve involved here with so many keyborad combinations and my old Microsoft Sidewinder joystick really is not up to the task, if you are serious about this sim you will need a decent joystick to fly with.  Personally I enjoy games that are much simpler to fly IE Wings Of Prey but that is just me.  I can see there is a lot of entertainment to be had with DCS, especially if you team up with some friends.  In conlusion. Yes it's a great game. Lots to remember, decent computer to play a full graphics.  Will I play it? Most likely not. To much else around offering the simpler game play I enjoy.

Granted you may be reading a book for about a month until you're at a minimum proficiency with the aircraft but the payoff is worth it. The sense of achievement that you get when you learn any of these aircraft is amazing as it's not just a case of pumping the throttle to maximum to take off like other plane games.   The future is very bright for this simulator as it is ever growing with more developers creating different aircraft for different theatres of war i.e. WWII / Korea / 80's/ Modern.

this game is perfecet ....

Not only aviation, you can take command on ground forces. Driving tanks and fire from the tunguska! And you can be a General! Controlled every unit at a battlefield. Super Realistic simulation and grand strategy wargame. Honestly, too much work needed for perfect gameplay as strategy.

This is a highly detailed SIMULATOR more then a game. if you want the simples of cockpits then the FC3 is where it is at with the F-15 or SU-27 and A-10A, if you want that full on clickable cockpit then the other modules is where its at but there is a large learning curve like about as close to learning to fly/operate the real thing as you can get.
expensive as hell, harder than hell to set up an learn, one hell of a game when you get it working.
It is the most realistic air combat simulator game.(my opinion)

I downloaded and attempted to run this game with the occulus rift. Boy was that a mistake.  The menu and HUD ignore head tracking, so you can't rebind any of your keys, or even see what they are already bound to because your eyeballs are not meant to see and read text at the very top of your vision. You were meant to move your head so that it enters your field of view.  The game itself is completely unplayable in VR. Everything has its own complicated keybinding ( Ctrl + Shift + Del = turn on power, F5 + num9 + roll your face on the left half of the keyboard is turn power off)  I'm sure plenty of basement dwellers enjoy that kind of immersion but it is COMPLETELY IMPOSSIBLE while you are wearing a VR headset. Why? Because you cannot see the keyboard to execute the overly complicated commands. Duh.  Maybe this is a revolution in gaming. I will never know.  Don't bother with this if you were hoping for an engaging VR experience.

I hate pay to win. Personally, I’d love to pay money for a game upfront and then get the entire package. Unfourunetly, this is not quite the case with games nowadays. It's become the norm to release a game for “free”, only to find that once you download the game, you are unable to use many features within the game unless you pay a premium.  This applies to DCS World.  The simulator I played prior to this had been War Thunder. The key difference between War Thunder and DCS world is that War Thunder features aircraft from World War Two, whereas DCS World seems to focus on the modern era.  The main reason I stopped playing War Thunder was because of the horrendous “pay to win” style of the game. I was truly excited about trying out DCS World, but my excitement was shattered as soon as I saw how much the aircraft packages cost.  For a moment, I put this aside. DCS World comes with two free aircraft, so I gave the SU-25T a try. I loaded up the “target practice” mission. A helicopter spawned somewhere infront of me, so I thought that it might be a nice idea to shoot it down. But, no matter what I did, I couldn’t get my weapons to fire. So I went to the internet to try and find out what was wrong.  So, I look online, and I find many different guides on how to fly the SU-25T. I open up a YouTube video and I look at the duration of the video; 20 minutes long for part 1/10! So not only do you have to pay a premium price for the planes in this game, but you have to spend hours just learning how to fly a single aircraft. I would be okay with this if the developers added a tutorial, but they seem to be too lazy to do this.  I am truly sickened by this product, and I am getting very tired of these cooperations taking advantage of their customers. Steer clear of this game, if you are looking for a free to play aircraft simulator, give War Thunder a try (if you can put up with the pay to win crap).

This is the free taster module that Eagle Dynamics are offering around, and as free samples go, this is a big one. All the functionality of the paid modules is included, with HOTAS and TrackIR 6DoF support. You get hundreds of square kilometres of terrain in this package, and access to one plane, the Su-25T. This is an updated version of the Su-25 (also available as DLC, £11.99 as of writing) with an incredibly wide range of potential loadouts for almost any sort of mission. The bundled editor lets you set up your own missions and weapons loadouts, or you can just jump straight in with the ready-made flights.  Of course, the reason that all of this is offered up for free is to get you hooked, there are many other flyable aircraft available for a price, with two distinct levels of complexity. The free Su-25T is the lesser of the two, which slightly reduces depth and immersion, but greatly increases accessibility. Also available as DLC at this level are the A-10A and Su-25, both competently designed CAS aircraft. If you want to take things up a notch, then there is a selection of aircraft with full cockpits that take many hours to learn. Furthermore, there is a DLC that allows you to control ground units including tanks and JTACs for guiding in airstrikes, if that's what floats your boat.  In conclusion, this is certainly worth the effort to learn about, if you are willing to put that effort in. For the action junkies, there is a ‘game mode’ that puts the training wheels back on and just lets you have fun, so pretty much anyone can enjoy this product, at whatever level you choose!

The DCS series are the best combat simulators out there, and this module is free so you've got nothing to lose. Don't be scared, you might have seen those A 10C startup videos and thought that was too much for you but there's a series of aircraft with simplified systems that are super easy to srtat flying (you start them pressing two buttons) but hard to master.   The world module is a perfect initiation in the DCS series as it offers those two experiences, the Su 25T has simplified systems while the TF 51D features all the real aircraft systems and clickable cockpit. If you are interested in the Flamming Cliffs 3 DLC I recommend learning to fly the Su 25 as it is a similar experience and of course if you are interested in the P 51 or the other WWII fighters try the TF 51.  My only complain would be some of the training missions for the Su 25T (the TF 51 doesn't have), they are very low quality videos from FC2. This isn't a big deal because it does feature a lot of interactive training missions, but the FC3 DLC planes only have those low quality videos which are a bit of a pain to watch. The rest of modules I have (A10C and P 51D) doesn't suffer from this and come with lots of step by step training missions.   Couple of suggestions:   - Play with a HOTAS or at least a Flight Stick, a gamepad works but it's not recommended.  - Do the training missions and pay attention, it's easy if you follow the instructions.  - Start with the Su 25T, flying the TF 51 requires experience.  - Create your custom keybings, mapping whichever buttons you feel you are using more to the Joystick.   - At the begining you might feel overwhelmed by the controls, focus first on flying the aircraft and leave the weapon systems alone until you can take of, land and navigate without problems.  - If you still feel this is too much, theres a GAME MODE under options, which gives you arcade style controls and radar, check the manual for further instructions on how to use it.  Overall amazing sim, 10/10 would crash again.

DCS World is, at least in my opinion, the best (combat) simulator out there.... It has so much variety, os pretty realistic and is all in all still a complex and very enteraining game in its own way. Even though the game has a very flat learing-curve, DCS World has a wide-spread community of people who are ready to help you learning this game due to YouTube Tutorials, via forums or just through the in-game chat function. Talking about a chat function the game has, for a simulator, a very good multiplayer where you can fly PvP, PvE, Coop,(...) missions or just join a squadron where you can enjoy this game with other players. Due to all that complexity ( and one of my favorite part: clickable cockpits) i can easily forgive the developers for having a DLC-driven policy ( the game itself is 'Free To Play' !!!). To play this simulator I heavily reccommend using a HOTAS Joystick (' Hands On Throttle And Stick') because you will not come really far by just using your keyboard. On thing i learned is that the community in this game is very mature so there are almost NO Trollers nor Flamer.  I really hope the community of this game will keep expanding ( as the game is further developed) and that i can see some of you in the air...

I love this sim. I recommend getting a hotas to play with pedals. I use the Saitek X52Pro. Some things to be aware of about the game. There are instructional videos. They take some time to go through. The current map is Georgia. no other maps available until the european theatre comes in september 2014. The next plane will be the mig-21 fishbed.   As far as the DLC goes, something specific. I would not get F15C:flaming cliffs. Just get flaming cliffs. You get 5 more planes for the cost you can get it on special for 40 dollars. Definitely a better value.   The flaming cliffs means that you cannot click the switches/turn nobs/hit buttons around the cockpit and lose some realism. I do defninitely recommend either the flaming cliffs or the p51 DLC's as your first purchase. The p51 is a bit nicer to use. When learning the planes its important to keep track of modes and buttons. I recommend doing this. I stream @  www.twtich.tv/ztokdo  and can help people to get started. Lovikdet6 is really helpful.   This is not an arcade game. Much of the air to air combat is BVR (beyond visible range) so keep that in mind. You frequently are not shooting at planes that you can see. radar makes beep beep, clickity click means a sam is fired at you. You have to learn how to crab/into shift to land in some areas.   Most recently they added more realism with 1.2.7/1.2.8. One of the biggest problems with the game is there are no multiseat aircraft and its not available in modding. The base game is updated about every 2-3 months, so keep that in mind. Its constantly getting more stable and the server play is getting a ton better.
